note.p: Birth: Mallow-on-the-Blackwater, County Cork, Ireland (30 October 1816)
Education: Apprenticed to a surgeon apothecary, Limerick; University College, London. MB (1840), MD (1842)

Career: Assistant Physician (1848), later Physician (1855), Brompton Hospital for Diseases of the Chest; Censor, Royal College of Physicians; President, General Medical Council; Physician Extraordinary to Queen Victoria (1890); edited 'A Dictionary of medicine' (1895); his practice included Thomas Carlyle and his wife, and Edwin Landseer
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc 1898 vol 63 pp vi-ix signed by J F
References: Vanity Fair 15 December 1883 - "Lord Beaconsfield's Physician" by 'Spy'
